retrieval rate in other words the speed with which you retrieve your data that determines your monthly retrieval fee if
you exceed your free retrieval allotment this kind of pricing will be familiar to those of you that deal with
955 bandwidth pricing we will consider a scenario where you have 60 terab stored
in Amazon glacia you store the data in Amazon glacia for a year during that
year there is one month where you need to retrieve 200 GB of data we also assume that your average archive size is
10 megabytes in order to calculate the request costs that are part of your monthly total cost of ownership or TCO
as we will refer to it in the first scenario you spread your
retrieval requests over two consecutive days retrieving 100 gbt the first day and 100 GB the second day
as 100 GB is less than your 102 GB free daily retrieval allotment you pay no
retrieval fees your 102 gab free daily allotment is simply 60 terabytes
multiplied by 5% divided by 30 days we're assuming a 30-day month for this
example your monthly total cost of ownership in this example works out to be about a penny per gigabyte per
month in scenario 2 you retrieve a 200 GB spread evenly over the course of one
day as you retrieved more than your free daily allotment there will be a retrieval charge for the month we are
assuming that this is the first day youve you have exceeded your free allotment in the month 200 gab spread evenly over 24
hours equates to a peak hourly retrieval rate of 200 GB divided by 24 hours which
equals 8.3 GB per hour however we need to account for your free allotment in
order to calculate your billable Peak hourly retrieval rate we prate your free
allotment on an hourly basis and then subtract it from your Peak rate which equates to a billable Peak hourly rate
of 4 GB per hour your retrieval rate is then calculated as 4 GB per hour
multiplied by a scent multiplied by the number of hours in the month which in this case is 24 hours time 30 days or
722 hours so your retrieval rate for the month is $29
when averaging your TCO over the 12-month period this results in a monthly TCO of 2 cents per gigabyte per
